thread.title: Seahawks dominate 49ers in 20-3 victory | Football
thread.title_full: Seahawks dominate 49ers in 20-3 victory | Football | ArcaMax Publishing

author: arcamax.com
title: Seahawks dominate 49ers in 20-3 victory | Football
text:
SANTA CLARA, Calif. -- There was no collapse this time.
Just domination from start to finish as the Seahawks scored a touchdown on their first possession and never let the 49ers make a game of it, beating them 20-3 Thursday in front of an increasingly quiet crowd at Levi's Stadium.
It was the seventh time this year the Seahawks held a lead in the fourth quarter. But this time there was no drama as Seattle used a stifling defense and trademark running game to hold on and improve to 3-4 this season. Here are the early grades:
Offense
Back in his home Bay Area stomping grounds, Marshawn Lynch turned in a vintage performance -- upset stomach and all -- finishing with a season-high 122 yards on 27 carries.
Lynch set the tone with nine carries for 38 yards on Seattle's opening 61-yard touchdown drive as the Seahawks used as many I-formation and two-back looks as they have all season. They also had as run-heavy of a game plan as they have had all season with 41 rushes to 24 passes.
The running success helped set up some of the play-action passes that have long been a staple of a successful Seattle offense, notably a 43-yard touchdown pass from Russell Wilson to Tyler Lockett late in the second quarter that made it 17-0. Lockett had the best day of his younger career with five receptions for 79 yards.
The Seahawks showed a lot of variety on the opening drive, with Lynch picking up 17 yards out of a two-tight end I-formation set on one play and then getting 16 on a pass out of a five-wide-receiver formation on the next.
Wilson almost was flawless early, hitting on 10 of his first 13 passes for 184 yards.
But his 14th pass was picked off in the end zone late in the first half as the Seahawks seemed prepared to knock the 49ers out early. Wilson tried to hit Doug Baldwin on the play in the back of the end zone.
Wilson threw another interception in the third quarter when he let it fly roughly 60 yards deep to Jermaine Kearse, with Kenneth Acker picking it off at the 7-yard line.
That gave Wilson five interceptions for the season -- he had seven all of last year and nine in 2013.
As the Seahawks went with a run-heavy plan, receiving numbers weren't high. Tight end Jimmy Graham, though, made his one catch early count, a 23-yarder that set up a field goal that made it 10-0.
Injuries forced the Seahawks to have to shuffle their line a few times, with Alvin Bailey stepping in at right tackle for Garry Gilliam in the second half -- Gilliam had been bothered by an ankle injury all week.
That contributed to what was again some shaky pass protection, and Wilson was sacked five times to bring Seattle's NFL-high sack total for the season to 31.
Defense
The Seahawks forced the 49ers to punt on all five first-half possessions and held San Francisco to 55 yards on 21 plays -- the 49ers got no closer than the Seattle 36-yard line in the first half and crossed midfield just twice all game.
The 49ers finished with just 142 yards and punted on nine of 10 possessions.
Cliff Avril and Michael Bennett have played as well as any set of defensive ends all season, and if anything they played even better against the 49ers.
The two combined for four sacks in the first half -- Bennett with 2.5 and Avril 1.5 -- as the 49ers punted on all five of their first-half possessions.
Avril then forced a fumble on San Francisco's first possession of the second half.
Bennett then forced a hold by Alex Boone early in the third quarter and added another sack a few minutes later.
Seattle finished with a season-high six sacks, Bennett with 3.5 and Avril 1.5, the most since the Seahawks had six against the 49ers last December in Seattle.
K.J. Wright, back at weakside linebacker, blew up a few screen plays early.
And the secondary played to a Legion of Boom level throughout. Richard Sherman was particularly key as he shadowed Torrey Smith everywhere and shut him out, depriving 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick of his best big-play receiver.
Rookie Frank Clark had some of the best moments of his young career, playing 15 of a possible 26 snaps in the first half and making 1.5 tackles, including a 3-yard loss of Carlos Hyde.
The 49ers tried to duplicate the success other teams have had of using the tight end. But Vernon Davis was a non-factor until a 27-yard pass late in the third quarter that led to a field goal.
Special teams
It seemed like Seattle escaped disaster a few times, with a punt almost blocked in the fourth quarter and the 49ers appearing close to breaking a couple of kickoff returns.
Ultimately, though, it was no harm, no foul.
Earl Thomas had two tackles on kickoffs, one preventing a possible touchdown.
Steven Hauschka hit two field-goal attempts and is 16 for 16 this season.
The Seahawks again had trouble shaking Lockett loose for much in returns, but on this night it didn't matter.
